questions.text: The below Image shows an instrument used frequently in the examination of glaucoma patients. Which one of the following statements is false about this instrument?

options.label: A
options.text: It is based on the Fick principle, which holds that the pressure inside an ideal sphere is equal to the force required to flatten the sphere divided by the area of flattening.

options.label: B
options.text: The diameter of flattening, 3.06 mm, is based on counterbalancing the corneal resistance and the capillary attraction of tears for the tonometer head.

options.label: C
options.text: The intraocular pressure (IOP) on the scale is equal to the force required to flatten the cornea multiplied by 10.

options.label: D
options.text: Like Schiotz tonometry, applanation tonometry reflects ocular rigidity.

questions.correct_answer: D. Like Schiotz tonometry, applanation tonometry reflects ocular rigidity.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Like Schiotz tonometry, applanation tonometry reflects ocular rigidity. Unlike Schiotz tonometry , applanation tonometry displaces a very small volume of aqueous humor from the eye and does not significantly increase intraocular pressure (IOP). For this reason, applanation measurements are essentially independent of ocular rigidity.

Highyeild:

Because of its simplicity, reliability, low price, and relative accuracy, it is the most widely used tonometer in the world.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option : A . Goldmann Applanation Tonometer is considered to be the gold standard instrument for the measurement of Intraocular pressure (IOP). It is an instrument that is based on the Imbert-Fick law . It is based on the Fick principle, which holds that the pressure inside an ideal sphere is equal to the force required to flatten the sphere divided by the area of flattening. Option : B . Goldmann applanation tonometer is based on the Imbert–Fick principle, which states that for a dry thin-walled sphere, the pressure (P) inside the sphere equals the force (F) necessary to flatten its surface divided by the area (A) of flattening (i.e. P = F/A) . It applies to surfaces that are perfectly spherical, dry, flexible, elastic, and infinitely thin. Theoretically, average corneal rigidity (taken as 520 μm for GAT) and the capillary attraction of the tear meniscus cancel each other out when the flattened area has the 3.06 mm diameter contact surface of the Goldmann prism , which is applied to the cornea using the Goldmann tonometer with a measurable amount of force from which the IOP is deduced. Option: C. This statement is correct.

Extraedge:

Schiotz tonometer consist of:- Handle -for holding the instrument in a vertical position on the cornea. Footplate - which rests on the cornea. Plunger - which moves freely within a shaft in the footplate

Solution:

Dynamic contour Applanation tonometry: measures IOP by providing force that flattens the cornea. Variable force applanation tonometers. (Goldmann, Perkins, Draeger, MacKay-Marg, and Tonopen) The dynamic contour tonometer represents a potentially new technology for non - invasive and direct intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement and has been proposed to accurately measure the true IOP irrespective of the corneal thickness. It is based on the principle that when the tip of the device exactly matches the contour of the cornea, the pressure measured by a transducer placed on its tip is an accurate indicator of the true IOP.

Highyeild:

This device is also capable of measuring the ocular pulse amplitude, a variable that has controversial significance in the diagnosis and management of glaucoma. A. Indentation B. Applanation C. Rebound

Extraedge:

Even though this technique seems to be very promising, further studies are required to conclusively determine the effectiveness of the dynamic contour tonometer in patients having an abnormal or irregular corneal contour.

questions.text: A first-year resident was performing a complete gonioscopy on a 56-year-old male patient. Which gonioscopic method is least likely to distort the anterior chamber anatomy and lead to an incorrect diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Koeppe The Koeppe lens is least likely to distort the anterior chamber anatomy. Koeppe gonioscopy is considered best for evaluating a patient with potential angle recession because this system allows easier comparison of one eye with the fellow eye or one portion of the angle with another.

Highyeild:

Limitations of Gonioscopy : Cannot be performed in a painful inflamed eye. Cannot be performed under mydriasis. Hyphema Compromised cornea lacerated or perforated globe.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Posterior pressure on the Goldmann lens may falsely narrow the angle by indenting the sclera. The Goldmann one-mirror lens, the Goldmann three-mirror lens, the Ritch lens, and the Magna View lens are all handled similarly. All have mirrors that are directed at the angle. In addition to the gonioscopic mirror, the Goldmann three - mirror lens has two mirrors through which the peripheral retina can be viewed. As with all slit-lamp goniolenses , the central optic can be used to examine the posterior pole of the fundus. The Goldmann lens provides an outstanding view of the optic disc and fundus Options: C & D. The Posner, Sussman, and Zeiss lenses are normally used with only the tear film coupling them optically to the cornea. Posterior pressure with the Zeiss lens will push the aqueous from the center to the periphery of the anterior chamber (AC). Occasionally, a drop of topical anesthetic , viscous tetracaine, or saline in the concavity of the lens will make contact easier. The lens is usually held squarely to the eye, which is the most comfortable position for both examiner and patient.

Extraedge:

The appearance of folds in Descemet’s membrane is an indication that too much pressure is being applied. It is better to allow intermittent loss of contact with the cornea and the resulting loss of any view than to allow excessive pressure to alter the exam.

Excessive fluorescein The given image shows applanation tonometry. If the fluorescein rings are too narrow, the IOP is underestimated. If they are too thick, the IOP is overestimated. The use of excessive fluorescein causes thick mires and an overestimation of IOP.

questions.text: The below image shows a manual perimeter capable of both static and kinetic perimetry. Based on histologic studies, what percentage of optic nerve axons may be lost before visual field changes are detected by this examination:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

0.5 The given image shows Goldmann perimetry. It is a manual perimeter capable of both, static and kinetic On the Goldmann perimeter, the test objects can be varied in both size and intensity by using different filters. It is known that pathologic changes in the optic nerve precede visual field changes. Up to 50% of optic nerve axons can be lost before any change is detected on the Goldmann visual field. This observation has stimulated interest in measuring the retinal nerve fiber layer thickness via imaging modalities.

Highyeild:

Different technologies have been developed and are being refined, most notably scanning laser polarimetry (GDx) and optical coherence tomography (OCT). These technologies will likely be useful to find early changes of glaucoma in addition to a careful ophthalmoscopic exam and clinical assessment

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presented with the following examination findings on gonioscopy. All of the following conditions are associated with these findings of the trabecular meshwork on gonioscopy except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Option: A. In a young normal eye, it is unusual to see any trabecular pigment band. This is because insufficient pigment has filtered through the trabecular meshwork to form a visible pigmented line. If pigmentation is apparent, it is usually most prominent in the inferior angle Option: B. The two most common conditions in which the pigment band is very prominent are pigment dispersion syndrome/pigmentary glaucoma and PXF glaucoma. Pigment dispersion syndrome (PDS ) is characterized by the liberation of pigment granules from iris pigment epithelium and their deposition throughout the anterior segment. Secondary pigmentary glaucoma (PG) is common. PDS and PG are more common in males, particularly young myopic white men. In primary PDS/PG, pigment shedding is precipitated by rubbing the posterior pigment layer of the iris against the zonules as a result of excessive posterior bowing of the mid-peripheral portion of the iris Option: C. Lesser amounts of trabecular pigmentation can be seen in iritis, diabetes, or following intraocular surgery, trauma, or laser.

Highyeild:

Pseudoexfoliative material is a grey-white fibrillary substance deriving from abnormal extracellular matrix metabolism in ocular and other tissues. The material is deposited on various ocular structures including the lens capsule as seen in the image below, zonular fibers, iris, trabeculae, and conjunctiva. Pseudoexfoliative material has been found in the skin and visceral organs, leading to the concept that PXS is the ocular manifestation of a systemic disorder.

Extraedge:

options.label: B

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Indirect ophthalmoscopy using a 20-D lens The small image obtained using indirect ophthalmoscopy does not allow for adequate evaluation of the optic nerve details.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Careful examination with a direct ophthalmoscope can provide important information about the pallor of the optic cup. Option B & D: The most effective methods include stereoscopic examination using the slit lamp in combination with a posterior pole contact lens, a 90-D lens, or a Hruby lens. Biomicroscopy of the fundus with the slit lamp is ultimately the result of melding the two most important examination techniques in clinical ophthalmology, namely biomicroscopy with the slit lamp and fundoscopy . The three lenses +90/+60/+40D are a good choice for imaging the whole spectrum of retinal diseases. Displacement of the oblique slit light can be used to assess changes in the surface profile of the inner retina which occurs e.g. in macular holes or pigment epithelial detachment.

Extraedge:

Nearly all retinal diseases can be imaged with the slit lamp - irrespective of whether they affect the posterior pole, mainly the optic nerve or the macula, the whole retina, or only its periphery. Even basic fundus-controlled perimetry is possible.
